Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Molecular Programming Architectures, Abstractions, Algorithms, and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The computing revolution began over two thousand years ago with the advent of mechanical devices for calculating the motions of celestial bodies. Sophisticated clockwork automata were developed centuries later to control the machinery that drove the industrial revolution, culminating in Babbage's remarkable design for a programmable mechanical computer. With the electronic revolution of the last century, the speed and complexity of computers increased dramatically. Using embedded computers we now program the behavior of a vast array of electro-mechanical devices, from cell phones and satellites to industrial manufacturing robots and self-driving cars. The history of computing has taught researchers two things: first, that the principles of computing can be embodied in a wide variety of physical substrates from gears to transistors, and second, that the mastery of a new physical substrate for computing has the potential to transform technology. Another revolution is just beginning, one whose inspiration is the incredible chemistry and molecular machinery of life, one whose physical computing substrate consists of synthetic biomolecules and designed chemical reactions. Like the previous revolutions, this "molecular programming revolution" will have the principles of computer science at its core. By systematically programming the behaviors of a wide array of complex information-based molecular systems, from decision-making circuitry and molecular-scale manufacturing to biomedical diagnosis and smart therapeutics, it has the potential to radically transform material, chemical, biological, and medical industries. With molecular programming, chemistry will become a major new information technology of the 21st century.

This Expeditions-in-Computing project aims to establish solid foundations for molecular programming. Building on advances in DNA nanotechnology, DNA computing, and synthetic biology, the project will develop methods for programmable self-assembly of DNA strands to create sophisticated 2D and 3D structures, dynamic biochemical circuitry based on programmable interactions between DNA, RNA, and proteins, and integrated behaviors within spatially organized molecular systems and living cells. These architectures will provide systematic building blocks for creating programmable molecular systems able to sense molecular input, compute decisions about those inputs, and act on their environment. To manage system complexity and to provide modularity, the project will establish abstraction hierarchies with associated high-level languages for programming structure and behavior, compilers that turn high-level code into lists of synthesizable DNA sequences, and analysis software that can predict the performance of the sequences. This will allow molecular programmers to specify, design, and verify the correctness of their systems before they are ever synthesized in the laboratory. In addition to these software tools, the project will study the theory of molecular algorithms in order to understand the potential and limitations of information-based molecular systems, what makes them efficient at the tasks they can perform, and how they can be effectively designed and analyzed. Putting the products of this fundamental research to the test, the project will pursue real-world applications such as molecular instruments for probing biological systems and programmable fabrication of nanoscale devices.

This project will expand the network of scientists and engineers working in molecular programming by building a diverse community of students, teachers, researchers, scientists, and engineers. This community will be fostered through the creation of publicly accessible software tools, courses, textbooks, workshops, tutorials, undergraduate research competitions, and popular science videos to teach the principles and methods of molecular programming and to engage young researchers and the public in this exciting new field. Industrial partnerships with relevant biotechnology and other high-tech companies will ensure fast transfer of knowledge generated into real-world products. Perhaps most importantly, as molecular programming becomes a widespread technology, it has the potential to transform industry with new complex nanostructured materials, to transform chemistry with integrated and autonomous control of reactions, to transform biology with advanced molecular instruments, and to transform health care with more sophisticated diagnostics and therapeutics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Inspired by the intricate and powerful molecular machinery of life, the long-term vision of this NSF funding is to develop a new discipline-molecular programming-that will encompass both the theory and practice of generating synthetic biomolecular systems. Our explorations of Molecular Programming Architectures, Abstractions, Algorithms, and Applications (MPP) have generated dozens of peer-reviewed publications that describe the application of synthetic DNA in the construction of nano-scale devices.  Besides new knowledge, this funding has resulted in the education of graduate and post-doctoral researchers, popularization of this science, multiple IP licenses, and a startup.

Outcomes and Intellectual Merit: The MPP has provided new insights and solutions to a broad collection of challenges in biology, chemistry, materials science, and medicine. Many of our advances can be characterized as fundamentally new ways in which DNA systems can be programmed, opening doors to a variety of downstream applications.  For example, in contrast to existing methods of creating nanoscale, self-folding DNA or RNA structures ("origami"), which incorporate hundreds or thousands of individual molecular strands, we have developed a novel design method utilizing only a single, long strand, paving the way to intracellular biological applications. We validated the design by constructing 23 structures comprising up to ~10,000 nucletotides.  Separately, we have built the largest-ever non-repetitive DNA structures, containing up to 30,000 unique strands and culminating in GDa-scale structures, and made progress in interfacing lipid nanostructures with DNA nanostructures for biological applications.  In order to scale up manufacturing of these large DNA structures, it is important to have an easy, cost-effective method of generating components strands.  As such, we developed the "SNAPCAR" method for scalable purification of multi-kilobase single-stranded DNA.

            We have also made progress in programming dynamic DNA processes.  For example, the timing of chemical processes plays important roles in biology and nanotechnology, but precise temporal control of single molecular events is challenging. We developed a general approach for the design of single-molecule clocks that permits control over the lifetime of single molecular interactions.  Additionally, we have developed a methodology to programmatically generate arbitrary single-stranded DNA sequences.  This programmable production has enabled us to demonstrate molecular recording, programmed strand cleavage, and logic computation.

            Other outcomes of this research funding were application-oriented.  Working in the field of synthetic biology, which seeks to mimic or utilize biological processes to engineering ends, we generated new methods of exerting precise control over cell function.  Termed "ribogegulators," these RNA structures allow specific input molecules to direct the production of specific proteins. The riboregulator designs have been used for rapid zika test on paper, establishing their potential in diagnostics.  Another challenge in applying synthetic DNA to biology is in thwarting the tendency of DNA structures to passively fall apart - or be actively destroyed by enzymes - as they are carried in the blood to a destination cell.  We demonstrated that specially-coated DNA nanostructures are stable in physiological salt concentrations and provide up to a 1,000-fold protection against enzymatic digestion. We next examined cell uptake of a panel of eleven distinct DNA-origami shapes, with largest dimension ranging from 50-400 nm, in three different cell types, and found that larger particles with a greater compactness were preferentially internalized. Finally, we leveraged our control over dynamic DNA interactions to create microscopy tools for biomedical research.  We demonstrated our DNA-based technique for visualizing individual molecules ("super-resolution microscopy"), of many different types, within a cell.  Visualized targets include DNA, RNA, and protein, including the tracing of chromosome shapes within cell nuclei that are altered in disease states.

Broader Impact: The MPP has expanded the network of scientists and engineers working in molecular programming through the creation of publicly-accessible software tools, courses, textbooks, workshops, tutorials, undergraduate research competitions, and popular science videos.  For example, Peng Yin and William Shih have consistently co-taught "Biomolecular Engineering and Synthetic Biology," focused on the rational design, construction, and applications of synthetic molecular machinery, and supported many graduate students and post-doctoral researchers with funding, materials, and guidance.  They also maintain the Wikipedia page on DNA nanotechnology, publish YouTube videos popularizing their research, invite local high schools for demonstrations, and organize the annual MPP meeting to exchange ideas and disseminate the recent developments in molecular programming. The Wyss Institute at Harvard has for its fourth year supported a "Molecular Robotics Initiative," lead by Drs. Shih and Yin, designed to initiate and nurture molecular sensing, programming, and actuation technologies.  This NSF-funded project has contributed heavily in ideas, technology, and students.  The project has resulted in the publication of dozens of journal articles, including several in high profile journals like Science and Nature, as well as dozens more patent applications and licenses.  Peng Yin recently launched "UltiVue" to commercialize the DNA-based microscopy tools developed here.
